Across the ocean in Dubai at BECO Capital we feel very much the same way about passionate founders solving hard problems with a differentiated plan! We’ll be following the success of Imbellus closely too :) Thank you for all your contributions to the ecosystem.

97f98e5df342.name: Both Sides of the Table

paragraphs.text: Building any business is hard, all-consuming, frustrating and fraught with personal challenges. When a founder is “opportunity driven” it’s too easy to quit at the first bump in the road. When a founder is “mission driven” you get the sense that he or she will do whatever it takes to make an impact in the market they serve and will keep persevering whatever the startup trends of the month.
paragraphs.name: 8fae
a26e
paragraphs.text: Fundamentally the system feels broken. We educate and train and test for a set of skills designed to succeed in 1950.

But we of course now live in a “knowledge economy” that has to constantly adapt to changing market conditions. As leaders we intuitively know that while basic skills in math, science, reading & writing are necessary — they are not sufficient.

I encourage entrepreneurs to try and tackle harder problems even if it makes fund raising more difficult and is less likely to succeed. As entrepreneurs many people are driven to solve their personal issues right in front of them, which leads a disproportionate number of founders to focus on: music, bars, restaurants, photos, etc.
paragraphs.name: e970
8fae
paragraphs.text: Building any business is hard, all-consuming, frustrating and fraught with personal challenges. When a founder is “opportunity driven” it’s too easy to quit at the first bump in the road. When a founder is “mission driven” you get the sense that he or she will do whatever it takes to make an impact in the market they serve and will keep persevering whatever the startup trends of the month.
